choices.text: Tooth decay did not occur due to micro nutrient deficiency
Conversion of hydroxyl group of hydroxylapatite forms fluoroapatite as protective layer
Post Translational modification of Collagen fibers are deficient leading to this condition
Calcification of Tendons and discolored mottled teeth can be seen in this condition

questions.text: 11 Year old Village Boy is presented with severe tooth pain and Sensitivity to Hot & Cold. On examination, Dental Carries has been found as shown in above images in multiple tooth. Village do not have community water supply. Identify the correct statement regarding nutrient Deficiency this patient is suffering.
questions.solution:
• Case history with tooth Pain, Sensitivity, Dental carries and water supply is suggestive of Micro-nutrient deficiency like Fluoride.
  • Option B): Fluoride replaces the hydroxyl group of Hydroxylapatite forming fluoroapatite that is more resistant to the enamel dissolving acid produced by mouth bacteria.
  • Fluoride deficiency, particularly in children, can lead to an increased risk of dental caries due to weakened enamel, allowing bacterial acids to penetrate and damage the tooth structure. This report discusses a case of fluoride deficiency leading to widespread dental decay.

Option A & D) Fluoride is added in water to prevent dental carries. Higher levels can cause skeletal fluorosis (Osteoporosis and calcification of tendons and ligaments)

Option C) Post Translational modification of collagen is required for cross linking of collagen fibers. It helps in formation of Interchain hydrogen bonds that stabilize the Triple helix structure. It requires presence of Vitamin C and deficiency leads to scurvy.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review - Biochemistry SA Edition, Chapter 33, Page number: 560

choices.text: Definitive Diagnosis requires examination of Synovial Fluid
Require to modify Anti Hypertensive Therapy
Uricosuric Agent are not useful for this patient
Febuxostat is used along with Colchicine during initial period

questions.text: Above Image is of 45 years old Hypertensive Patient on Thiazide diuretics with preserved Renal Function presented with history of Joint Swelling, Redness and Pain as shown in above images since 03 month. Management requires all except
questions.solution:
• The scenario describes a hypertensive patient on thiazide diuretics with a history of joint swelling, redness, and pain, suggestive of gout, a common side effect of thiazide diuretics. Thiazides can increase uric acid levels, potentially leading to gout attacks.
  • Option A) Gout is disorder initiated by high level of uric acid as a result of Overproduction or under excretion. Hyperuricemia can lead to the deposition of Monosodium Urate crystals in the joints and an inflammatory response to crystals leads to acute gouty attack. Definitive diagnosis requires examination of synovial fluid
  • Option B) Thiazide diuretics can increase uric acid levels, so modifying or switching the antihypertensive medication (e.g., to losartan or calcium channel blockers) is a reasonable consideration to avoid exacerbating gout.
  • Option C) As mentioned in clinical history, Patient's renal functions are normal. In given clinical case there is under-excretion of Uric Acid so Uricosuric agents are useful for this patient.
  • Option D) As the patient is suffering from Acute Pain, Joint Swelling and redness over affected area suggestive of Inflammatory Condition. Colchicine prevents formation of Microtubules thereby decreasing movement of Neutrophils into the affected area. Simultaneously, Febuxostat, a non purine inhibitor of Xanthine oxidase helps in decrease production of Uric Acid.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 34, Page number: 583

choices.text: Fatty Liver is common finding in this condition
Weight for Height is markedly decreased

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in connection to Child shown In above image.
questions.solution:
• Image shows Nutritional disorder - Protein Energy Malnutrition specifically Marasmus.
  • In this condition there is calorie deprivation is greater than the reduction of protein. It is most commonly seen in children younger than age 1 year when breast milk is supplemented with watery gruels of native cereals deficient to Protein and Calorie.
  • Symptoms seen in marasmus are arrested growth, Extreme muscle wasting and depletion of subcutaneous fat , weakness. Fatty liver is common finding in Kwashiorkor - PEM not in Marasmus. Other differentiating features is Depigmented Hair, Decreased Albumin Concentration & Pitting edema more commonly seen in Kwashiorkor.

Option A) In kwashiorkor, due to lack of sufficient protein intake and calories from carbohydrate may be adequate, Insulin levels suppress lipolysis and proteolysis along with deposition of fat in the liver.

Option B) In marasmus, weight for height is markedly decreased instead kwashiorkor Weight for Height is either normal or decreased.

Option C) In children suffering from Marasmus, Refeeding of severely malnourished child can result in Hypophosphatemia because any available phosphate is used to phosphorylate carbohydrate Intermediates.

Option D) In developing countries inadequate intake of Protein and Energy is major cause for PEM. While in Developed country, it has been named as Protein Energy Undernutrition which is after any disease, trauma etc.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 31 Page Number: 511

questions.text: Above image shows Glucose Tolerance test curves. If Urine Sugar is ++ (Present) at 1 hour after 75 gm of Glucose Load in Patient #1, what is your probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• As shown in above image, Three different Glucose Tolerance test curves signifies three different conditions,
  • Glucose tolerance test is done for Diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus, Impaired Glucose Tolerance or pathological causes leading to glucose intolerance in body.
  • Glucose tolerance is the ability to regulate the blood glucose concentration after the administration of a test dose of glucose (normally 1 g/kg body weight) The normal glucose tolerance is determine by the timing of and quantity of insulin secreted and the ability of tissues to response to insulin.
  • Impaired glucose tolerance seen in liver damage, some infections, and in response to some drugs, hyperactivity of the pituitary gland etc.
  • Glucose is continuously filtered by glomeruli but it actively reabsorbed back from renal tubule & capacity is upto rate of 2mmol/min (350mg/min) . Renal Threshold for glucose is Blood Glucose value 180mg/dl. In excess of Blood Glucose level, Glycosuria (presence of Glucose in urine ) appears. But in some pathological conditions / renal conditions
  • where renal threshold is lowered leading to presence of Glucose in urine at much lower level of Blood Glucose leading to Pathological Glycosuria.

As in above case history, after Glucose load, in Patient #1 although blood sugar value at 0 hour, 1 hour and 2hours are within normal range. But presence of Urine sugar at 1 hour that is more likely suggestive of Renal Glycosuria - Pathological.

  • Clinical Significance of Glucose Tolerance Test:
    • Normal Glucose Tolerance: Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hr < 100, Post 2 hr <140
    • Impaired Glucose Tolerance: Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hrs between 100-125, Post 02 hr between 140-1200
    • Impaired fasting Blood Glucose; Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hrs between 100-125 rest are normal
    • Diabetes Mellitus; Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hrs is ≥ 126, Post 2 hour ≥200

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Chapter 19, page number:189

choices.text: Elevated Level of Phenylalanine in Urine

questions.text: Above image shows changes in Vertebrae having dense black pigment deposited on the intervertebral disks in Metabolic Disorder due to enzyme deficiency. What is the reason of turning black of urine color in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Metabolic Disorder mentioned in above case summary is Alkaptonuria. Finding of Black Pigments in intervertebral Disk, changes of Urine color - black & metabolic cause with enzyme deficiency is suggestive of Homogentisate Oxidase defect which catalyze the Homogentisate to Methylacetoacetate.
  • Accumulated Homogentisate, excrete in urine and due to oxidation of Homogentiase urine darkens on exposure of air leading to Black color of Urine.
  • In alkaptonuria, later in disease, Ochronosis (Connective tissue Pigmentation) is due to oxidation of homogentisate to benzoquinone acetate, which polymerizes and binds to connective tissue seen as black pigmentation on Intervertebral Disc.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review Biochemistry SA Edition, Chapter 25, page number: 409

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition, chapter 29, Page number: 296

questions.text: A -09 month old presented with swelling of leg. Above image shows presence of fracture of bowed femur, thin bones. Blue Sclera is present. Past history suggestive of multiple fractures in various bones in healing stage. Which is among the best suitable for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Above image with given case scenario having history fracture, blue sclera in younger age more likely suggestive of Collagen Vascular Disorders. All including Ehlers Danlos syndrome, Scurvy and Osteogenesis Imperfecta is related with Collagen disease.
  • Multiple Fractures in various bones with Blue Sclera at the age of 09 month is more suggestive of Osteogenesis Imperfecta.
  • Genetic disorders of collagen biosynthesis include several forms of osteogenesis imperfecta, characterized by fragile bones. Type 1 OI, the most common form is characterised by mild bone fragility, hearing loss and blue sclera.
  • Option a) In the Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a group of connective tissue disorders that involve impaired integrity of supporting structures, defects in the genes that encode α collagen-1, procollagen N-peptidase, or lysyl hydroxylase result in mobile joints and skin abnormalities.

Genes or enzyme affected in Osteogenesis Imperfecta is COL1A1 /COL1A2.


Option B) Vitamin C is required for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases. The consequent deficit in the number of Hydroxyproline and Hydroxy lysine residues undermine the conformational stability of collagen fibers, leading to bleeding gums, swelling joints, poor wound healing.

Option D) Vitamin D Deficiency is commonest cause of developing Rickets in children, Bones of Children are under mineralize due to poor absorption of Calcium. Bow Leg, Rachitic Rosary and Harrison sulcus are symptoms and signs present in Ricket.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Biochemistry - SA Edition, Chapter 9, Page number: 129

choices.text: Both a and b are correct

questions.text:
Above images shows classical sign of Collagen Vascular Disease. Read the Sentences and Identify the Correct Answer.

a. Skin Extensibility is caused by defects in Type V collagen.
b. Vascular Form of Ehlers - Danlos syndrome had Autosomal recessive Pattern
c. This syndrome caused by Deficiency mutation in the amino acid sequence of Collagen
d. Dominant Negative effect is seen in this disease
questions.solution:
• Ehlers-Danlos syndrome comprises a group of inherited disorders whose principal clinical features are hyperextensibility of the skin, abnormal tissue fragility, and increase joint mobility. This Classical form of EDS is due to defect in Type V collagen.
  • Vascular form due to defect in type III collagen - most serious form of EDS associated with lethal arterial rupture. It shows Autosomal Dominant inheritance.
  • EDS caused by deficiency of collagen processing enzyme or due to mutation in the amino acid sequences of collagen Type I, III & IV.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Chapter 50, Page number:603

questions.text: Above image shows Enzyme Inhibition by malonate (Enzyme - Succinate Dehydrogenase). Identify the type of Enzyme Inhibition.
questions.solution:
The relationship between reaction velocity (v) Vmax and the Michaelis Constant (Km) is described by Michaelis - Menton Equation. It is useful for understanding enzymatic reactions. As shown in image Vmax remain same but Km is changed suggestive of Competitive Inhibition.

Option A) In Competitive Inhibitior, Inhibitor binds with substrate binding site by blocking the access by the substrate

Option B) In non competitive Inhibitor , Inhibitor binds enzyme at distant site than substrate binding site. In non competitive inhibition, Vmax is decreased but Km remain constant. Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition. E.g Pyruvate Kinase inhibited by Alanine.

OptionC) Uncompetitive inhibitors do not compete with the substrate for binding to the active site, and they only bind to the enzyme-substrate complex.

Option D) Suicidal Inhibiton involving Enzyme undergoes self destruction in order to terminate its own activity. E.g Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine Oxidase

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated review SA Edition, Chapter 10, Page number: 142-143

choices.text: Defective Hydroxylation of Prolyl and Lysyl Hydroxylation
Cross Linking of Collagen fibers is adequately present
Reaction requires Ferric Ion, H+ and ascorbic Acid
Subcutaneous Fluid collection leading to Ecchymoses

questions.text: Above image shows characteristic sign of Ecchymoses due to deficiency of Micronutrient. What is the pathogenesis behind above presentation?
questions.solution:
• The Deficiency of vitamin C results in scurvy. The clinical Features are Swollen Joints, Fatigue, Irritability, Bleeding into the skin, Perifollicular Hemorrhage, pseudoparalysis.
  • Majority of the Deficiency symptoms are due to deficient collagen synthesis. In deficiency of vitamin C, Post translational modification of collagen fibers, hydroxylate of Prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen did not occurs.

Defective Cross linking of collagen fibers is seen. It requires presence of Ferrous Ion and Molecular Oxygen.

Patient with scurvy often show ecchymoses (Bruise like discolouration) on the limbs as a result of subcutaneous extravasation of blood due to capillary fragility and not due to fluid.

Other features of Scurvy includes Osteopenia, Cortical Thinning, Subperiosteal Haemorrhage, Scorbutic Rosary, Pelken Spur may be seen on radiological examination.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 32, Page number: 528

choices.text: Mutation in gene for leptin results in Hyperphagia
Leptin's effect are mediated through arcuate nucleus of hypothalamus
Increase in Calorie intake, increases Leptin Secretion by Adipocytes
More Commonly Obese Individual are leptin deficient

questions.text: Above images are A) Before Leptin therapy and B) after Leptin Therapy. Identify the incorrect sentence regarding biochemical basis of role of Leptin in obesity Prevention.
questions.solution:
The molecular Influences behind obesity is mainly depends on neural and humoral pathways that regulate Appetite, Energy Expediture and body weight involve systems that regulate short term food intake and signal for long term regulation of body weight.

  • Various Long term signals reflects the status of Fat Stores. Main Enzyme involves in long term signal is leptin.
  • Leptin is an adipocyte peptide hormone that is made and secreted in proportion to the size of fat stores. It acts on brain to regulate food intake and energy expenditure.
  • So during more calorie consumption, Leptin production increases leads to more energy expenditure and anorexogenic effect. So in deficiency state of Leptin, it will not occur & leads to obesity.

Mutation in the gene for leptin or its receptor result in hyper phagia and sever obesity.

Most obese individual have elevated leptin levels but are resistent to the appetite regulating effect of this hormone.

Leptin's Effect is mediated through binding to receptors in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Biochemistry SA Edition, Chapter 30, Page number: 485-486

questions.text: A -30 years old Male presented with above cutaneous manifestation on sun exposed areas along with increase in urine uroporphyrin levels ,what should be your probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cutaneous manifestation seen in above image over the sun exposed area is skin eruption due to accumulation of porphyrin mainly seen in most common type of Porphyria - Chronic Hepatic Porphyria - also known as Porphyria Cutanea Tarda.
  • The disease is associated with Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. It is mainly Autosomal Dominant Disorder. Clinical Manifestation depends on hepatic iron overload, exposure to sunlight, alcohol ingestion, oestrogen therapy and seen in fourth / fifth decades of life.

  • Conversion of Uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III is deficient leading to increase in Uroporphyrin levels also appears in urine.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review Chapter 26, Page number: 419-420

questions.text: Images shows peripheral blood smear showing Heinz Bodies. All Pathological Conditions in which Heinz Bodies are seen except
questions.solution:
Polycythemia Vera: This condition is not typically associated with Heinz bodies. It involves increased red cell mass but not hemoglobin denaturation in the same way as the other conditions.

Option A) Oxidation, due to decreased levels of GSH and increased levels of intracellular oxidants (eg, O2- ), of SH groups of Hb leads to formation of denatured protein forms insoluble masses called Heinz bodies.

G- 6 pD Deficiency impairs ability of the cell to form the NADPH that is essential for the maintenance of the G-SH pool.

This results in a decrease in the detoxification of free radicals and peroxides formed within cell. It helps to maintain the reduced state of sulfhydryl groups in Hemoglobin.

So in G- 6 PD deficiency leads to formation of heinz bodies.


Option B) thalassemia is disorder associated with Abnormal synthesis of Globin chain due to mutation in either Alpha or beta globin gene leading to decreased production or absent of synthesis of globin chain. Heinz bodies are also inclusion bodies that are formed in patient suffering from Thalassemia Major where B thalassemia Major, b globin chain in synthesis of Hemoglobin is absent leading to precipitation of Alpha globin chains inside the RBC forming Heinz Bodies.

Option D) Dapsone, an oxidative drug, can cause Heinz body formation due to oxidative stress on red blood cells.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 18 Page number-256-57

questions.text: A patient is suffering from Acute Diarrhea since 03 days. Identify the correct Acid Base Imbalance from the above diagram the patient is suffering from
questions.solution:
• Above diagram explains changes occurs in pH and HCO₃ values in different conditions leading to Acid Base Imbalance.
  • In chronic Diarrhea, there is direct loss of fluid rich in bicarbonate from the Gastrointestinal tract. To maintain electric Neutrality of the blood, chloride is reabsorbed back and Anion Gap remains normal and H+ ion concentration increases leading to Metabolic acidosis.
  • In this condition pH less than 7.35 and HCO₃⁻ ion < 22 mmol/L which is seen in option C and marked in image as III. Compensation by Respiratory system and Hyperventilation.

Option B) Metabolic Alkalosis: (Marked as II in image) ]

Primary disturbance: Increase in HCO₃⁻

  • pH: Increased (> 7.45)
  • HCO₃⁻: Increased (> 26 mEq/L)
  • Compensation: Respiratory system compensates by hypoventilating to retain CO₂ (PaCO₂ increases)

Option A) Respiratory Acidosis: Marked as (I)

  • Primary disturbance: Increased PaCO₂ (due to hypoventilation or respiratory failure)
  • pH: Decreased (< 7.35)
  • HCO₃⁻: Initially normal, but may increase if renal compensation occurs (to buffer excess acid)
  • Compensation: Kidneys retain HCO₃⁻ to neutralize the excess CO₂ (slow process)

Option D) Respiratory Alkalosis: Marked as IV

  • Primary disturbance: Decreased PaCO₂ (due to hyperventilation)
  • pH: Increased (> 7.45)
  • HCO₃⁻: Initially normal, but may decrease if renal compensation occurs (kidneys excrete more HCO₃⁻)
  • Compensation: Kidneys excrete HCO₃⁻ to reduce pH (slow process)

Reference: Biochemistry- Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 4 Page number: 40-41

questions.text: Identify the Lipid Storage disorder showing characteristic Picture of Splenic Cells Biopsy under the microscope.
questions.solution:
• In splenic cell biopsy, Foamy appearing cells contains Sphingomyelin is seen in Niemann Pick Disease. This disorder is related with Sphingomyelin and lysosmal enzyme Sphingomyelinase is deficit leading to impairment in degradation of Sphingomyelin. It is autosomal recessive disorder and as liver and Spleen are primary site for lipid storage it enlarged.

Option B) Von Gierke's Disease:

A glycogen storage disorder, not a lipid storage disorder.

  • It involves a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase and primarily affects the liver and kidneys.
  • There are no characteristic lipid-laden cells in the spleen.

Option C) In fabry's disease accumulation of Globosides due to defect in alpha Galactosidase. It is X linked disorder. Red Skin Rash, Kidney damage and Heart Failure, Burning pain over lower extremities are present.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 22 - Page number: 328.

choices.text: Arcus senilis due to Cholesterol Deposition
Mutation is seen in ATP7B gene

questions.text: Above images shows brown color dis-colouration due to deposition of Pigments in Nutritional Disorders. Identify the correct Statement.
questions.solution:
Image shown above is of Kayser fleischer Ring (Corneal Deposit of Copper) seen in Wilson's Disease.

Disease is Autosomal Recessive, efflux of Cu from the Liver by ATP7B is imparied. Cu Accumulated in the liver, leaks into the blood and deposited in brain, eyes, kidney and skin.

In another disorder related with Cu metabolism is Menkes syndrome. It is x linked disorder also known as kinky hair disease where efflux of Cu out of intestinal enterocytes into the circulation by a Cu Transporting ATPase ATP7A is impaired.

Arcus senilis is due to cholesterol deposition - a sign of Atherosclerosis more commonly seen in Metabolic disease, Hyperlipidemia patients.

Cu containing enzymes are Cytochrome Oxidase, Dopamine B Hydroxylase, Ferroxidases, Lysyl Oxidase, Tyrosinase.

Reference: Biochemsitry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 33, Page number: 556
